title: Ricky Woznichak
text:
I‚Äôm Ricky Woznichak, a passionate digital marketing professional and current M.S. candidate in Digital Marketing at Cal Poly Pomona. Prior to my stint as an actor, I cut my teeth as an Assistant Digital Media Planner at UM, crafting campaigns for clients like Sony Home Entertainment and IHOP. Along the way I also honed my storytelling and people skills as a substitute teacher and‚Äîtrue story‚Äîan awesome waiter. I‚Äôve led SEO initiatives, mastered tools like Google Analytics and SEMrush, and built interactive R and Quarto dashboards that turn complex insights into clear action. When I‚Äôm not geeking out over forecasting models for my Productfolio.com thesis, you‚Äôll find me strolling with my dog Jimmy ‚Äî because great ideas often strike when you‚Äôre off screen.
You can find my entire journey on Linkedin - Let‚Äôs Connect!





California State Polytechnic University, Pomona | California | June 2010





California State Polytechnic University, Pomona | California | August 2025





John Franklin Insurance | Marketing Manager | 2024-2025
Los Angeles Unified School District |Substitute Teacher & Special Education Teacher | 2019‚Äî2024
Mama Shelter, Esterel, Mixto | Server + Banquet Server |2013‚Äî2024
Studio71 | Sales Development Coordinator | 2012‚Äî2013
Universal McCann | Assistant Digital Media Planner |2011‚Äî2012
Universal Music Group | Digital Marketing Coordinator | 2010‚Äî2011

title: About
text:
About this site

1 + 1

[1] 2

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
We can create a summary table and modify it for various statistical analyses using the {gtsummary} package.



Versatile Output: Supports summary statistics, regression models, survival analysis, and more ‚Äî all formatted beautifully.
Customizable: Easily change labels, statistics, and formatting without needing to manually tweak tables.
Publication-Ready: Outputs clean, APA-style tables with minimal effort ‚Äî ideal for reports, papers, and presentations.
Reproducibility: Tables are generated directly from your analysis pipeline, reducing the risk of transcription errors.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
üì¶ Why {gtsummary} Matters

Versatile Output: Supports summary statistics, regression models, survival analysis, and more ‚Äî all formatted beautifully.
Customizable: Easily change labels, statistics, and formatting without needing to manually tweak tables.
Publication-Ready: Outputs clean, APA-style tables with minimal effort ‚Äî ideal for reports, papers, and presentations.
Reproducibility: Tables are generated directly from your analysis pipeline, reducing the risk of transcription errors.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
üéìüìà How It Can Help Us

In School:

Create polished tables for homework, theses, or presentations.
Save time formatting ‚Äî focus more on the analysis itself.
Impress your professors with professional-grade outputs.

In Your Career:

Quickly generate high-quality tables for client reports, internal documents, or academic publications.
Streamline analysis workflows with reproducible and automated reporting.
Integrate with tools like Quarto, R Markdown, and Shiny apps for interactive or dynamic reporting.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
section: How does gtsummary differ from gt and gtExtras?
text: How does gtsummary differ from gt and gtExtras?

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
gt

Purpose:¬†A core package for creating¬†flexible and beautiful tables¬†in R.
Strength:¬†Great for¬†custom-designed tables¬†from scratch, especially for presenting summary stats, formatted text, etc.
Usage:¬†You have to¬†manually define¬†your data transformations and table formatting.
Think of it as:¬†A powerful table engine, similar to¬†ggplot2¬†but for tables.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
gtExtras

Purpose:¬†A set of¬†helper functions¬†that work on top of¬†gt¬†to¬†make common formatting tasks easier.
Strength:¬†Adds shortcuts for enhancements like:

Heatmaps
Sparklines
Fancy styling presets

Usage:¬†It extends¬†gt¬†and saves time on visual and layout improvements.
Think of it as:¬†Add-ons to style and beautify your¬†gt¬†tables quickly.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
gtsummary

Purpose:¬†Built specifically for¬†statistical reporting and clinical-style summary tables.
Strengths:

Automatically identifies variable types (continuous, categorical, dichotomous).
Builds¬†‚ÄúTable 1‚Äù-style summaries¬†with a single line of code.
Easily adds:

P-values (add_p())
Confidence intervals
Regression summaries (tbl_regression())
Inline reporting

Highly customizable using¬†tidyselect¬†syntax.

Uses¬†gt¬†under the hood¬†for the table rendering.
Think of it as:¬†A¬†reporting-focused abstraction layer¬†that does 90% of the formatting and logic for you.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
Inline Reporting with inline_text()

You can¬†pull values directly from a table into your R Markdown text¬†‚Äî like odds ratios, p-values, or confidence intervals.
Example:
"The odds ratio for age isr inline_text(tbl, variable = ‚Äúage‚Äù)."
Keeps your¬†results synced automatically¬†with your tables ‚Äî no manual copy-paste needed!

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
Formula Syntax for Customizing Variables

Customize labels, types, stats, and digits using¬†formula-like syntax¬†(e.g.,¬†variable ~ value).
Supports tidyselect helpers like¬†all_continuous(),¬†starts_with("age"), etc.
Lets you¬†target multiple variables with one line¬†for streamlined styling.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
section: Merge and Stack Tables Easily (tbl_merge(), tbl_stack())
text:
Merge and Stack Tables Easily (tbl_merge(), tbl_stack())

Combine multiple tables:

Side-by-side (e.g., univariable vs.¬†multivariable regression)
Top-to-bottom (e.g., adjusted vs.¬†unadjusted estimates)

Helps you¬†build complex, publication-quality tables¬†without breaking a sweat.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text: Gtsummary Chart

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
The P-Value:
A p-value of 0.001 from the Chi-square test suggests that there is a statistically significant association between keyword intent and ranking position for productfolio.com. Considering that the p-value is much lower than 0.05, which is the commonly used significance level, we reject the null hypothesis that there is no relationship between keyword intent and position. Stated differently, certain keyword intent types (informational, commercial, etc.) meaningfully influence where Google search results rank websites. This means that some keywords may attract higher traffic than others for this domain niche, and this information can be used in future content planning or SEO.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text: Thank You Very Much

text:
2.2 gt

Purpose:¬†A core package for creating¬†flexible and beautiful tables¬†in R.
Strength:¬†Great for¬†custom-designed tables¬†from scratch, especially for presenting summary stats, formatted text, etc.
Usage:¬†You have to¬†manually define¬†your data transformations and table formatting.

Strength:¬†Adds shortcuts for enhancements like:

Heatmaps
Sparklines
Fancy styling presets

Usage:¬†It extends¬†gt¬†and saves time on visual and layout improvements.
Think of it as:¬†Add-ons to style and beautify your¬†gt¬†tables quickly.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
2.4 gtsummary

Purpose:¬†Built specifically for¬†statistical reporting and clinical-style summary tables.
Strengths:

Automatically identifies variable types (continuous, categorical, dichotomous).
Builds¬†‚ÄúTable 1‚Äù-style summaries¬†with a single line of code.
Easily adds:

P-values (add_p())
Confidence intervals
Regression summaries (tbl_regression())
Inline reporting

Highly customizable using¬†tidyselect¬†syntax.

Uses¬†gt¬†under the hood¬†for the table rendering.
Think of it as:¬†A¬†reporting-focused abstraction layer¬†that does 90% of the formatting and logic for you.

You can¬†pull values directly from a table into your R Markdown text¬†‚Äî like odds ratios, p-values, or confidence intervals.

title: Summary Tables with gtsummary
text:
4.2 The P-Value:
A p-value of 0.001 from the Chi-square test suggests that there is a statistically significant association between keyword intent and ranking position for productfolio.com. Considering that the p-value is much lower than 0.05, which is the commonly used significance level, we reject the null hypothesis that there is no relationship between keyword intent and position. Stated differently, certain keyword intent types (informational, commercial, etc.) meaningfully influence where Google search results rank websites. This means that some keywords may attract higher traffic than others for this domain niche, and this information can be used in future content planning or SEO.

title: Dashboard Example
Dashboard Example
section: Column - Medals By Sport and Year
text:
Column - Medals By Sport and Year

Row - Medals by Sport

summer_olympics |>
  mutate(
    sport = fct_lump_n(sport, n = 15),
    sport = fct_infreq(sport),
    sport = fct_rev(sport),
    sport = fct_relevel(sport, "Other", after = 0)
  ) |>
  ggplot(aes(y = sport, fill = medal)) +
  geom_bar(color = "white") +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE)) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Gold" = "#d4af37",
      "Silver" = "#c0c0c0",
      "Bronze" = "#cd7f32"
    )
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = seq(1000, 7000, 1000), 
    labels = label_number(big.mark = ",")
) +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = NULL,
    fill = "Medal"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "inside",
    legend.position.inside = c(0.8, 0.2),
    legend.direction = "horizontal",
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "gray")
  )










Row - Medals By Year

Due to World War II, no Olympic Games were held in 1940 and 1944.

summer_olympics |>
  count(year, medal) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = n, color = medal)) +
  geom_point(size = 0.8) +
  geom_line() +
  guides(color = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1896, 2020, 8)) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c(
      "Gold" = "#d4af37",
      "Silver" = "#c0c0c0",
      "Bronze" = "#cd7f32"
    )
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = NULL,
    color = "Medal"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = c(0.2, 0.8),
    legend.direction = "horizontal",
    legend.background = element_rect(
      fill = "white",
      color = "gray"
    )
  )

Warning: A numeric `legend.position` argument in `theme()` was deprecated in ggplot2
3.5.0.
‚Ñπ Please use the `legend.position.inside` argument of `theme()` instead.

title: Dashboard Example
text:
Column - Medals By Country

Row - Value boxes

summer_most_golds <- summer_olympics |>
  filter(medal == "Gold") |>
  count(team, sort = TRUE) |>
  slice_head(n = 1)

summer_most_silvers <- summer_olympics |>
  filter(medal == "Silver") |>
  count(team, sort = TRUE) |>
  slice_head(n = 1)

summer_most_bronzes <- summer_olympics |>
  filter(medal == "Bronze") |>
  count(team, sort = TRUE) |>
  slice_head(n = 1)


Most Golds:
2363
United States


Most Silvers:
1251
United States


Most Bronzes:
1126
United States



Row - Tabsets of tables

Teams sorted in descending order of total medals.

summer_olympics |>
  count(team, medal) |>
  pivot_wider(names_from = medal, values_from = n, values_fill = 0) |>
  mutate(total = Bronze + Gold + Silver) |>
  arrange(desc(total), team) |>
  slice_head(n = 30) |>
  select(Team = team, Gold, Silver, Bronze) |>
  gt() |>
  cols_align(align = "left", columns = Team) |>
  data_color(
    method = "numeric",
    palette = "nord::aurora"
  )

section: Column - Medals by sport and year
text:
Column - Medals by sport and year

Row - Medals By Sport

winter_olympics |>
  mutate(
    sport = fct_lump_n(sport, n = 15),
    sport = fct_infreq(sport),
    sport = fct_rev(sport),
    sport = fct_relevel(sport, "Other", after = 0)
  ) |>
  ggplot(aes(y = sport, fill = medal)) +
  geom_bar() +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE)) +
    scale_fill_manual(
    values = c(
      "Gold" = "#d4af37",
      "Silver" = "#c0c0c0",
      "Bronze" = "#cd7f32"
    )
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = seq(100, 2000, 100), 
    labels = label_number(big.mark = ",")
) +
  labs(
    x = NULL,
    y = NULL,
    fill = "Medal"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "inside",
    legend.position.inside = c(0.8, 0.2),
    legend.direction = "horizontal",
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "gray")
  )










Row - Medals By Year

Due to World War II, no olympic games were held in 1940 and 1944.

winter_olympics |>
  count(year, medal) |>
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = n, color = medal)) +
  geom_point(size = 0.8) +
  geom_line() +
  guides(color = guide_legend(reverse = TRUE)) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1896, 2020, 8)) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c(
      "Gold" = "#d4af37",
      "Silver" = "#c0c0c0",
      "Bronze" = "#cd7f32"
    )
  ) +
  labs(
    x = "Year",
    y = NULL,
    color = "Medal"
  ) +

    legend.position = c(0.2, 0.8),
    legend.direction = "horizontal",

title: 4.22 SemRush AO4
text:
# Load the dataset
data <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")


# Inspect column names (you've already done this)
colnames(data)

[1] "Keyword"            "SERP.Position"      "Search.Volume"     
[4] "Keyword.Difficulty"



# Step 3: Create log-transformed Search Volume
data$log_volume <- log(data$Search.Volume + 1)


# Step 4: Create the interaction term
data$interaction <- data$log_volume * data$Keyword.Difficulty


# Step 5: Fit the multiple linear regression model
model <- lm(SERP.Position ~ log_volume + Keyword.Difficulty + interaction, data = data)


# Step 6: View the results
summary(model)


Call:
lm(formula = SERP.Position ~ log_volume + Keyword.Difficulty + 
    interaction, data = data)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max

library(tidyverse)

‚úî purrr     1.0.4     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ

# Load your dataset
keywords_df <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")


# Create a log-transformed search volume column
keywords_df$log_volume <- log(keywords_df$Search.Volume + 1)


# Optional: Clean SERP positions if needed
keywords_df <- keywords_df %>% filter(!is.na(SERP.Position))


# Create the scatterplot
ggplot(keywords_df, aes(x = log_volume, y = SERP.Position)) +
  geom_point(aes(size = Keyword.Difficulty, color = Keyword.Difficulty), alpha = 0.8) +
  scale_y_reverse() +  # Lower SERP positions are better
  scale_color_gradient(low = "#00BFC4", high = "#F8766D") +
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(2, 8)) +
  labs(
    title = "SERP Position vs. log(Search Volume)",
    subtitle = "Bubble size and color represent Keyword Difficulty",
    x = "log(Search Volume)",
    y = "SERP Position (Lower is Better)",
    color = "Keyword Difficulty",
    size = "Keyword Difficulty"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "right",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  )









# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)


# Load your dataset
keywords_df <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")

# Create log-transformed search volume
keywords_df$log_volume <- log(keywords_df$Search.Volume + 1)

# Filter out missing values
keywords_df <- keywords_df %>% filter(!is.na(SERP.Position))


# Set thresholds for difficulty and volume
difficulty_threshold <- 50  # Difficulty below 50 is ideal
volume_threshold <- median(keywords_df$Search.Volume, na.rm = TRUE)  # Use median for this dataset


# Assign quadrants
keywords_df <- keywords_df %>%
  mutate(
    Opportunity = case_when(
      Keyword.Difficulty < difficulty_threshold & Search.Volume >= volume_threshold ~ "High Opportunity",
      Keyword.Difficulty >= difficulty_threshold & Search.Volume >= volume_threshold ~ "Competitive",
      Keyword.Difficulty < difficulty_threshold & Search.Volume < volume_threshold ~ "Niche Opportunity",
      TRUE ~ "Low Priority"
    )
  )


# Plot Keyword Opportunity Matrix
ggplot(keywords_df, aes(x = Keyword.Difficulty, y = Search.Volume, color = Opportunity)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_text_repel(aes(label = Keyword), size = 3, max.overlaps = 12, box.padding = 0.4) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = difficulty_threshold, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray40") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = volume_threshold, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray40") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c(
    "High Opportunity" = "#00BFC4",
    "Competitive" = "#F8766D",
    "Niche Opportunity" = "#7CAE00",
    "Low Priority" = "gray60"
  )) +
  labs(
    title = "Keyword Opportunity Matrix",
    subtitle = "Based on Search Volume and Keyword Difficulty",
    x = "Keyword Difficulty",
    y = "Search Volume",
    color = "Opportunity Zone"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )

increasing max.overlaps

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(gt)

# Load data
keywords_df <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")

# Create styled table with Keyword Difficulty as percent
keywords_df %>%
  select(Keyword, Search.Volume, Keyword.Difficulty, SERP.Position) %>%
  arrange(SERP.Position) %>%
  gt() %>%
  tab_header(
    title = "Keyword Performance Table",
    subtitle = "Keyword Difficulty displayed as percent"
  ) %>%
  fmt_percent(
    columns = Keyword.Difficulty,
    decimals = 0,
    scale_values = FALSE  # Because your values are already in 0‚Äì100 range
  ) %>%
  fmt_number(
    columns = Search.Volume,
    decimals = 0
  ) %>%
  cols_label(
    Keyword = "Keyword",
    Search.Volume = "Search Volume",
    Keyword.Difficulty = "Difficulty",
    SERP.Position = "SERP Rank"
  )

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)

# Load your dataset
keywords_df <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")

keywords_df <- keywords_df %>%
  mutate(
    `Keyword Difficulty` = paste0(round(Keyword.Difficulty, 0), "%")

  select(
    Keyword,
    `SERP Position` = SERP.Position,
    `Search Volume` = Search.Volume,
    `Keyword Difficulty`
  ) %>%
  arrange(`SERP Position`)

# Display as table
kable(keywords_df, caption = "Keyword Summary Table with Difficulty as %")

# Load your dataset
keywords_df <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")

# Create a log-transformed version of search volume
keywords_df$log_volume <- log(keywords_df$Search.Volume + 1)

# Drop rows with missing values (if any)
keywords_df <- na.omit(keywords_df)

# Optional: View structure
str(keywords_df)

'data.frame':   29 obs. of  5 variables:
 $ Keyword           : chr  "define digital product" "product framework" "product market matrix" "complexity matrix" ...
 $ SERP.Position     : int  6 6 7 5 6 4 5 5 6 6 ...
 $ Search.Volume     : int  90 110 880 90 30 110 320 70 110 210 ...
 $ Keyword.Difficulty: num  0.43 0.34 0.38 0.24 0.2 0.3 0.25 0.18 0.29 0.12 ...

# Run the Random Forest model
rf_model <- randomForest(SERP.Position ~ log_volume + Keyword.Difficulty,
                         data = keywords_df,
                         ntree = 500,          # Number of trees
                         importance = TRUE)    # Show variable importance

title: 4.22 SemRush AO4
text:
# Load the dataset
data <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")


# Inspect column names (you've already done this)
colnames(data)

[1] "Keyword"            "SERP.Position"      "Search.Volume"     
[4] "Keyword.Difficulty"



# Step 3: Create log-transformed Search Volume
data$log_volume <- log(data$Search.Volume + 1)


# Step 4: Create the interaction term
data$interaction <- data$log_volume * data$Keyword.Difficulty


# Step 5: Fit the multiple linear regression model
model <- lm(SERP.Position ~ log_volume + Keyword.Difficulty + interaction, data = data)


# Step 6: View the results
summary(model)


Call:
lm(formula = SERP.Position ~ log_volume + Keyword.Difficulty + 
    interaction, data = data)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-1.6631 -0.5741  0.1947  0.4175  1.4310 

Coefficients:
                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept)          2.1242     2.3475   0.905    0.374
log_volume           0.6450     0.4783   1.349    0.190
Keyword.Difficulty   9.5944     5.8037   1.653    0.111
interaction         -1.7291     1.0675  -1.620    0.118

Residual standard error: 0.8725 on 25 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.1041,    Adjusted R-squared:  -0.003455 
F-statistic: 0.9679 on 3 and 25 DF,  p-value: 0.4234

library(tidyverse)

# Load your dataset
keywords_df <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")


# Create a log-transformed search volume column
keywords_df$log_volume <- log(keywords_df$Search.Volume + 1)


# Optional: Clean SERP positions if needed
keywords_df <- keywords_df %>% filter(!is.na(SERP.Position))


# Create the scatterplot
ggplot(keywords_df, aes(x = log_volume, y = SERP.Position)) +
  geom_point(aes(size = Keyword.Difficulty, color = Keyword.Difficulty), alpha = 0.8) +
  scale_y_reverse() +  # Lower SERP positions are better
  scale_color_gradient(low = "#00BFC4", high = "#F8766D") +
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(2, 8)) +
  labs(
    title = "SERP Position vs. log(Search Volume)",
    subtitle = "Bubble size and color represent Keyword Difficulty",
    x = "log(Search Volume)",
    y = "SERP Position (Lower is Better)",
    color = "Keyword Difficulty",
    size = "Keyword Difficulty"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = "right",
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold")
  )









# Load necessary libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(ggrepel)


# Load your dataset
keywords_df <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")

# Create log-transformed search volume
keywords_df$log_volume <- log(keywords_df$Search.Volume + 1)

# Filter out missing values
keywords_df <- keywords_df %>% filter(!is.na(SERP.Position))


# Set thresholds for difficulty and volume
difficulty_threshold <- 50  # Difficulty below 50 is ideal
volume_threshold <- median(keywords_df$Search.Volume, na.rm = TRUE)  # Use median for this dataset


# Assign quadrants
keywords_df <- keywords_df %>%
  mutate(
    Opportunity = case_when(
      Keyword.Difficulty < difficulty_threshold & Search.Volume >= volume_threshold ~ "High Opportunity",
      Keyword.Difficulty >= difficulty_threshold & Search.Volume >= volume_threshold ~ "Competitive",
      Keyword.Difficulty < difficulty_threshold & Search.Volume < volume_threshold ~ "Niche Opportunity",
      TRUE ~ "Low Priority"
    )
  )


# Plot Keyword Opportunity Matrix
ggplot(keywords_df, aes(x = Keyword.Difficulty, y = Search.Volume, color = Opportunity)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.8) +
  geom_text_repel(aes(label = Keyword), size = 3, max.overlaps = 12, box.padding = 0.4) +
  geom_vline(xintercept = difficulty_threshold, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray40") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = volume_threshold, linetype = "dashed", color = "gray40") +
  scale_color_manual(values = c(
    "High Opportunity" = "#00BFC4",
    "Competitive" = "#F8766D",
    "Niche Opportunity" = "#7CAE00",
    "Low Priority" = "gray60"
  )) +
  labs(
    title = "Keyword Opportunity Matrix",
    subtitle = "Based on Search Volume and Keyword Difficulty",
    x = "Keyword Difficulty",
    y = "Search Volume",
    color = "Opportunity Zone"
  ) +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title = element_text(face = "bold"),
    legend.position = "bottom"
  )

# Load libraries
library(tidyverse)
library(knitr)

# Load your dataset
keywords_df <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")

# Format Keyword Difficulty as a percentage (character string)
keywords_df <- keywords_df %>%
  mutate(
    `Keyword Difficulty` = paste0(round(Keyword.Difficulty, 0), "%")
  ) %>%
  select(
    Keyword,
    `SERP Position` = SERP.Position,
    `Search Volume` = Search.Volume,
    `Keyword Difficulty`
  ) %>%
  arrange(`SERP Position`)

# Display as table
kable(keywords_df, caption = "Keyword Summary Table with Difficulty as %")

library(randomForest)

randomForest 4.7-1.2


Type rfNews() to see new features/changes/bug fixes.



Attaching package: 'randomForest'


The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':

    combine


The following object is masked from 'package:ggplot2':

    margin



# Load your dataset
keywords_df <- read.csv("4.21CurrentKeywords.csv")

# Create a log-transformed version of search volume
keywords_df$log_volume <- log(keywords_df$Search.Volume + 1)

# Drop rows with missing values (if any)
keywords_df <- na.omit(keywords_df)

# Optional: View structure
str(keywords_df)

'data.frame':   29 obs. of  5 variables:
 $ Keyword           : chr  "define digital product" "product framework" "product market matrix" "complexity matrix" ...
 $ SERP.Position     : int  6 6 7 5 6 4 5 5 6 6 ...
 $ Search.Volume     : int  90 110 880 90 30 110 320 70 110 210 ...
 $ Keyword.Difficulty: num  0.43 0.34 0.38 0.24 0.2 0.3 0.25 0.18 0.29 0.12 ...
 $ log_volume        : num  4.51 4.71 6.78 4.51 3.43 ...



# Run the Random Forest model
rf_model <- randomForest(SERP.Position ~ log_volume + Keyword.Difficulty,
                         data = keywords_df,
                         ntree = 500,          # Number of trees
                         importance = TRUE)    # Show variable importance
